newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Kabila's troops fire in air to stop Congo protest.
newsitem.headline: Kabila's troops fire in air to stop Congo protest.

text.p: Troops fired into the air on Friday to break up a protest in Kinshasa against a new government formed in the Democratic Republic of Congo, witnesses said.
"A group of demonstrators were heading towards the parliament building and the soldiers opened fire in the air," one witness said. There was no immediate indication of any casualties.
Earlier, supporters of opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi took to the streets of Kinshasa in a peaceful march to protest against his exclusion from the new government, witnesses said.
About 300 to 400 chanting Tshisekedi supporters also called for the departure of Rwandan and other foreign soldiers in Laurent Kabila's Alliance forces who captured Kinshasa last weekend.
A Reuters journalist followed the march from Tshisekedi's house in Limete into the city centre, past the U.S., French and Belgian embassies.
The demonstrators chanted slogans calling Kabila a dictator but no violent incidents were reported, even when the marches filed past Alliance patrols.
